children.text:
New Year's and play
Nina Simone in the bedroom while we
twirl like conductors batons and point
to where the notes should have been.

We sometimes cry in corners and curse
the air for its lack of affection.

Our womb pleads for us to take
notice while we crush the past
underneath our heels and condemn
ourselves to the fire next time.

We sometimes punctuate
the earth with our beauty.

And challenge the galaxy with our
smiles we sometimes transform.
Because evolution is in us all.
And to prove Satan a liar.
And

we sometimes take life by the
hand and peel her like an orange.
Slowly, slowly.

Wendell
Otley, followed by Yapet Brinson.
Good afternoon.

My name is Wendell Otley, and um,
I want to thank you first before I
start, since I won't when I'm finished.
Um, my poem is Damnation.

Come from behind the protection of the
white sheets you've worn, the piles of the
ashes of the crosses you've burned, the

stinking rotting corpses of the niggers
you've lynched, and face your damnation.

Pretend that my problems don't
exist, that I'm just bitching
for no reason in particular.

That I'm full of shit, and
you will face damnation.

Continue to show an abundance of
my negative side, without giving
equal weight to my positive.

To show me as a menace to society, but
find no faults in the society I menace.

To arrest me for committing a
blue collar crime, but acquit
yourself of white collar crimes.
And you will suffer damnation.

Ask, why am I not happy being a lower
case letter in your capitalistic system?

Why am I not satisfied with the rats and
roaches that come with low income housing?

Why am I not filled from head to toe
with hot dog and apple pie chanting
USA every four years patriotism?

And I will say, because I didn't
ask to come to this damn nation.
Yafet
Brinson, followed by DJ Renegade.
Hey, what up?
How's it going?
My name is Yafet.

The poem is called Roman
Catholic Hit and Run.

Yesterday, a black cop, while crossing
the street, was hit and killed by
two black nuns on a mountain bike.

The cop dude didn't have a chance
to pull his trigger, call for
backup, down that day old donut,
or polish his plastic badge.
You see, the cop wasn't paying attention.

He crossed in between, not at
the green, saw nothing at all
of oncoming traffic, didn't even
look before stepping off the curb.
Besides, the nuns had right of way anyway.

And no, no funeral was given,
no investigation was done.

All that remained were the skid marks
of the Roman Catholic nigger nuns.
D.
J.
Renegade, followed by Ta-Nehisi Coates.

Somebody go
wake up Shakespeare and tell
him DJ Renegade's in the house.

Subterranean night colored magi,
three moods in the mode of Miles.
Subterranean means underground.

Deep, profound, and Miles
was one deep brother.

Miles deep like a shaft, descending to
the mother load, blowing undersongs.

Miles on tenor trumpet, tenor eleven
levels deeper than the next cat.

Painting all up under the canvas,
making it blue bleed out the other side.

Blowing solo, only we
hear his bedrock blues.
Underground cultural resistance.

A virtual virtuoso battling musical
mafiosos burrowing under their skin.

Miles, the son of a dentist doing
root work with a hoodoo horn hollering
bebop toast like he was Petey

Wheatstraw, Satchmo's son in law, or
Stagger Lee stabbing mediocrity with
a sharpened fifth, or a signifying

junkie jumping cold turkey out the
lion's mouth, or shine below the deck
of the Titanic, bluing up the boilers.

You see, Miles could blue like bird and
freight like train, early like bird and
night like train, wing like bird and
rail like train, tunneling underground.

A night color is blacker than
a thousand asphalts and Miles
was one deep black brother.
Black and mysterious as smoke.

Black as the sky, round
midnight, round midnight.

Black as the pot that
stewed a bitch's brood.

Black and turning like a tire,
treadmarking musical notation
on the asphalt of life.

Miles was slick as black ice, cool as
black snow, sweet as black cherries,
hitting harder A black Jack Hammer, black
Jack Johnson, or a black Jack Daniels.

See, Miles was a Jack of spades, but an
ace at his trade, blowing night colors.

Like deep black, triple black,
shiny black, cinder black, ashy
black, quarter black, mega black,
multi black, all shades of Miles.

Shifting harmonic gears
in his chromatic Ferrari.

Blowing with his black
turn to the audience.

Speaking coolly Magi are priests,
wailing wizards, soloing sorcerers.

And Miles was one deep
black magic brother.
Miles, conjuring in the key of we.
Magi, Magi, that's the confused ones.
Miles is singular, they say.
But Miles, we know you plural, you y'all.

You be bop miles, hard bop
miles, cool miles, fusion miles.

Lord, Lord, Lord, you reverend
miles, tonally testifying
from the book of the blues.

Blowing muted magic like
chapter and verse, making a
joyful noise unto the Lord.

And anybody else hip
enough to dig the scene?

Magi Miles with crazy
styles, even sported a tutu.
Miles, 1.
6 kilometers of cool.
Miles, 5, 280 dancing feet.

Miles, too much distance for their
musical rulers, pouring decades
of music like vintage wine.

Miles, wily, never smiley, too
quick to hit and took no shit.

Nobody's fool, sleek, satin,
cool, anciently new, kind of blue.
Our subterranean, night colored magic.
Ta-Nehisi
Coates, followed by Dorothy Marie Wright.

Um,
I am Ta Nehisi Coates.
That's alright, everybody do it.
Um, and I'm from Baltimore.

Um, but I came down here, I
guess, with the DCP, because
that's where I go to school.

I'm gonna read a piece
entitled, Last Night.
It goes like this.

On this dark of bottomless night, She
returns, touching, quiet, making us
Silhouette swimmers in an ocean of sheets.

What I have missed is my hand
gracing tender up the arc of her
back and her whispering music
before the tune escapes my lips.

What I have wanted is her so nuclear
with wanting that she melts sun and
paints the sky plum purple with passion.

And the stroke is so good that
I jump crazy at the sudden of
my alarm as it screams reality
across the mess of a lonely room.

I peep the digital demon whose
red eyes wail six o'clock.
And now I know why I hate mornings.

They always leave me
holding pillows like lovers.

Dorothy Marie
Rice followed by Michael Collins.

As I read this
poem, well, before I read this poem,
I want to make a comment to Bert,
my friend, and say, I won't explain.
He understands.

And also give homage to Gwendolyn
Brooks, who said, it's okay to
have a poem that's not crafted.
This was written this morning.
Ambrosia.
Hush.
Somebody's calling your name.

The first buzz you hear, tiny
as a raindrop, is the Scout.

She travels miles on
sturdy wings, thin as mica.
Miles through ozone drenched currents.
Miles past housing projects.
Miles.

Miles past bald headed little
boys, pot bellied little
girls, and weary grandmothers.

Finally, a field, wild flowers,
clover, she tongues the purple
sweetness, baptizes herself, returns
to her kin, miles and miles away.
Children, go where I send thee.

We swarm, nestle ourselves
in the bosom of mountains.

Our hymns, a chorus, reverberating,
breaking sound barriers.

Michael
Collins, followed by Tony Blackman.
My name is Michael L.
L.
Collins.
I'm from Indianapolis, Indiana.

I'm a jazz poet, and I love reading
jazz poems, and I love the fact that
out there there are not only other

poets, but poets out there with
books, and poets out there teaching.

So it means also that I have,
there's an audience that listens,
it's not just waiting here to read.

But anyway, I read one time, and I,
like I said, I love doing my jazz
poems, I read one time in Indianapolis,

I read one of my jazz poems, and Mari
was out in the audience, and uh, You
know, I thought I did pretty good.

She said what you did
wasn't of any substance.
I said, damn, you're right.

Because I had read back to it
and it wasn't of any substance.

She said it didn't address
any issues in the community.
I said, damn, you're right.

I said, uh, got to do a
little bit more writing.

And there were some important
issues in the community and
important issues where I was at.
And I was going to church at the time.

So I thought I'd write a little bit
about the church, and uh, I wanted to
say, there's one important question when
you go to church that you need to ask.
That is, ask, who gave the money?
Ask, where does the money go?
Now, sisters, ask the preacher.
To read with you from the book of Mark.

Now ask if the Bible is opened
when he opens the finance books.

Ask if the message in one book can
answer the message in the other.

Ask him to turn to chapter
12, verse 38 through 44.
Ask him to preach from that passage.
Ask them to preach it's meaning.
Now ask,
why are there no women trustees?

Ask, why no sisters sit
on the deacon board?
Ask, why brothers ask sisters not to ask?
Where does the money go?
Then, counter him.

ount to him the number
of sisters in the church.

Count to him the sisters who serve
on the usher board, who sing in the
choir, and tell him not to forget
those who teach in the Sunday schools.
Yeah.

Count to him the small
number of men in the church.

Count to him the number of
times you've heard that only
brothers can count the money.

They have to count the money
early in the afternoon.

Because baseball,
basketball, football, boxing.
I said boxing.
They create conflicts.
And they just can't stay late.
Except,
oh yeah, except.
Except if there's a special service.
Like that time the champ was called.
Yeah, it was that special Sunday.

The champ, Iron Mike Tyson was
called to walk down the aisle.
And he gave an exceptional donation.
All the brothers were there.
Preacher was there.
You should have been there
to ask.
Ask him to open that book again.
Yeah, ask him to read that message again.

Ask him to read the part about
when the collection was taken.

Ask him to read the part about
when that multi multi millionaire
gave that multi multi money.
And that little itty bitty woman.
Oh, she gave a little itty bitty bit.
Read your Bible now.
Ask who the Bible said gave the most.
Now, then ask.

Ask if the church's Sunday school
teacher says that she's been raped.
Raped by that same sports hero,
Iron Mike Tyson.

That same Seventh Commandment
breaking sports hero.
Ask, who will the church believe?
Ask, if his book is still open.
Finance book
or Bible book.
Ask, who gave the money?
Ask, where does that money go?

Toni Blackman,
followed by Jonathan Gray.
Toni Blackman, followed by Jonathan Gray.
The black woman's struggle.

Her head swings low like
Sweet's chariot, but she ain't
coming forth to carry you home.

She and her sister,
carrying too much as it is.
Hello, my name is Toni Blackman.
I want to give a shout out to E.
Ethelbert Miller.

One of the reasons that I've
been writing for so long.
Irving G.
Russell.
He's a very helpful brother.

I write a lot of four poems that have
maybe seven words in them at the most.

So, um, I think today that's
what I feel like reading.

And this one is called
Accident at the Church.

The steeple toppled into the parking
lot, causing the parishioners to scream,
to actually care about one another.
Spell number three.

I tried to write a poem about your
eyes, but you kept staring at me.
Intercourse.

Last night I made love to
myself for the very first time.

There was absolutely
nothing painful about it.
Every Sunday.

Miss Lucy in that old tired red velvet hat
struts the avenue as if it were the night.

And my final piece is written for my
brothers who chant the pussy song.

Obsessed with vaginal chants
of regions of acts of nonsense.
Not moving us forward, stagnant we remain.

Clutching to those concepts with
which they have brainwashed us,
with which they have controlled us.
Sex can be hypnotic if you allow it to be.

Sex can be an escape
if you allow it to be.

The only true escape
from reality is death.

And we are allowing it to
happen one by one by one by one.
We are an endangered species.
Sex is not for our people, no.
We cannot allow it to happen.
For we, we must make love.
Applause

Next we have Jonathan
Gray, followed by Kwame Alexander.
Jonathan
from Howard University.
Peace to all the brothers from 8 Rock.

Um, if you think this poem applies
to you, then it probably does.
What?
You don't really want to battle.

Are you buggin Comin at me with some
old muley mouth bullshit about why can't
the brothers and sisters get along.
Fuck that, fake punk.

You know you only kickin that shit so you
can have sex with a pseudo revolutionary,
nappy headed, falsetto intellectual who is
jockin you because you have a nose ring.
A nose ring.
And you surely ain't no bull like I am.
Preachin about respect.
You don't respect what I stand for.

Always talking about represent,
hmm, what the fuck do you represent?

Bourgeois black trust fund baby
trying to be real, phony punk, what?
I know you ain't saying nothing.

Doing this rhythm and poetry
to rebel against your parents.
I don't have parents.
My mother dropped me off when I was 12.
I was old.
I have suppositions.
And you want to battle me?
Bitch ass nigga, step!

I ain't got nothin to live
for, and nothin to lose.
So what, nigga?
Step.
Yeah, that's what I thought.

Kwame Alexander,
followed by, uh, Nehassaiu deGannes.
What's happenin

Much props to my daughter,
Nandi, the creator.
Poet from D.
C., 8 Rock.
It's your mug.
Stage Black.

My favorite piece of a journal slash
book that I'm editing called The Flow.
New black poetry in motion.
Manpower.
Appetizer.
Strawberries.
Orange slices.
Pineapples.
Grapes.
Apples.
So I ask her, What about the watermelon?

She reads me like a page out of
the Afro listic Guide to Nutrition.
You never mix citrus fruits with melons.

Start with the scratch,
and there will be no itch.

We must return to the
old ways, to the old way.
Abandon that which is new and confusing.

Just because it's modern,
don't make it real.
It just become temporary, like my job.

Paid 5 G's a week to smile at corporate
fearing would be Tarzans with jungled
bellies who make 5 G's a day to smile

at corporate wannabes who waste no time
making well thought of jokes about OJ.
Obey your thirst, drink Sprite.
Obey your drink, thirst Sprite.
Drink your Sprite, obey thirst.
Thirst your drink, obey Sprite.
Obey Sprite, obey Sprite.

The blacker the smile,
the sweeter the pension.

The slower the walk,
the faster the lynching.
We remember Roots, the latest version.

Written, directed, produced, conceived,
created, marketed, and starring.
Introduction, I don't recall.

Part one, the untouchable,
airborne nigger.

Part two, the innocent, crotch
grabbing, more than black nigger.
And the saga continues with part three.

The most recent
unstoppable airport nigger.
Caution, niggers.

Mixing citrus fruits with melons is
hazardous to you and your health.
Lately, everything has become sexual.

The way you walk, the way we talk,
and even my job has become sexual.

Want to stick my disc in the
drive and load my software.
Error.
Unable to read the disc.
The program worked last week.

So I checked my hardware and discovered
that the problem is my memory.

I discovered that the
problem is my memory.
Was it French or Italian?

The tomatoes and olives should
be seasoned with feta cheese.

Break the lettuce into half
inch pieces and then add the
croutons and the radishes.
Mix everything in one bowl and chill.

We walked the slow walk, the
walk of zombies and snow.

We don't owe nobody, don't own
nobody, and don't know nobody
who listens to Garth Brooks.

Khaled Mohamed maybe,
but not Garth Brooks.

Leonard Jeffries maybe,
but not Garth Brooks.

Maulana Karenga maybe,
but not Garth Brooks.

Professor Egypt himself,
but not Garth Brooks.

How you gonna practice an ancient
philosophy in 1994 and expect
it to work for you when it
didn't work for them in four?
Silly rabbits, Afrocentrics are for kids.

Grownups walk in the sun, avoid
snow at all costs, and attend narrow
nationalist pre Afro historic lectures
as much as they listen to Garth Brooks.
The phone rings.
It's 6.
It's not her.

Fresh green peppers, diced onions,
marinated in tamari overnight.

oil for three minutes.

I removed a package of Japanese stir
fried vegetables from their freezer,
where they had been sitting overnight.
Enter mock duck.
Not real duck, fake duck.
Fake deal.
Real late.
She's supposed to be here.
I'm supposed to be finished.

Supposing it's 8 o'clock
and she still ain't here.
Supposing the game is on in one hour.
Supposing she comes at 8.
45 and expects to eat.
Supposing she don't call.
She don't.
Supposing I sit down to eat by myself.

Supposing I finish eating and
sit down to watch the game.

Supposing I find that the game has
been preempted by another game.
I thought he retired.
Maybe him just tired.
Replenish the body, black people.
Feed the mind, African people.
Reawaken the soul, Sun people.
Chocula for the children.
Food for the dissatisfied buppies.
Chocula for the CBC.
Food for the NAACP.
BET.
BDP.
BBD.
You and me.

Everything that survives
on this planet needs food.
Ask the questions, poets.
Answer the questions, scientists.
Probe the mind.
Teach the truth.
Grow the child.
Till the soil.
Plant the earth.
Work the body.
Study the mind.
Watch the people.
Love the people.
Cross the desert of your black mind.
Cross the desert of your mind.
Sprinkle water on black brain cells.
Sprinkle water on your brain cells.
Reward your desert with spring water.

Return to the way of the flow
of the water of our people.
Beware.

The wrong river will take you to
distant places like wacko Texas, and
South Carolina highways, and 7 by 9
foot cells, and separated marriages,

and lonely nights, and tapped phones,
and repossessed cars, and ripped
condoms, and overdue flowers, and 9

to 5s, and renovated plantations, and
late retirements, and multiple organ
failures, and late dates, and late dates.
And late dates.

Glancing on the kitchen table, I
see my paste up, wondering, when
will I get tired of this job?
The three month itch is almost up.

When will I retire, or better
yet, when will they tire of me?

I mix the citrus fruits with the
melons, the nicks with the rockets,
and escape to my TV room where I eat

three months of insecurity, pain,
laughter, and joy in three minutes.

I stood up, contemplate whether
leaving the juice would make
me any less Afro neolistic.
Suddenly, the phone rings at 10.
I answer.
The voice asks, How are you?
It's her.

She who doesn't see the wine, and
the glasses, and the vegetables,
and the duck, and the juice,
and the juice, and my tears.

Didn't I tell you I had
to get my hair done today?
Hair today, gone tomorrow.
She asks, What's on my mind?

I hesitate, wondering whether I
should tell her that I mix the
citrus fruits with the melons.

Instead, I choose to calm her
unnecessary guilt ridden simplicity
with the fruitful culmination of
my evening long introspection.

Everybody's conscious,
but when we gonna eat?
Peace.

In case you
missed it, Brother Alexander's
book is for sale upstairs.
Uh, check it out.

Um, next we have Nehassaiu

for us having this forum.
and after that, Erica Jackson.

I'm an
African American poet, African
American in the hemispheric sense.

I was born in the Caribbean
and grew up in Canada.
I'm considered an alien in this country.

Double Dutch girls in West Philadelphia
Jump sidewalk cracks home Not breaking
mama's back is Sun straddling grid
work And heavy iron trellis of an L

overpass Cuts tic tac toe into ashy
skin The tall one, Shaneen, choosing
just the right moment to talk.
Her talk angles her tongue like a spoon.

Tissa kissed Raheem, put her
tongue full in his mouth.

Thick black braids and running
shoes, swoop like birds of
prey circling up to dive again.

Tongues circle and dive, ululating
iron like cistern at a whaling wall.

Darkness shivering to the
high pitched ring of steel.
So how you know?
Winged flesh hunts out innocence.
Sucking gaps in back of full grown teeth.
Eyes roll sticks of juicy fruit.
Now or later, lips smack and pop.

Comparing him to red popsicles, Kiss
to cool a high noon heat, A girl's
own sweat, Glistening on upper lip,
Tongue darting in, tongue darting out,

Measuring meter and testing rhyme, The
thwap of ropes, Against the pavement,
the pavement, the flap of rope against
black ground cowie tongues curled.

Just so are a third eye, a sensor,
dividing every black girl's destiny.

Telling each one when to trust
the angle of the turning rope.
Telling each one exactly when to jump.

And my second poem, I'd like to, um,
dedicate it to friend of mine whose
birthday is coming up soon in almost.

Almost a year ago, when we first met, this
is the poem I read to him over the phone.
A Woman's Rights.

Aching goods deciphering ocean Bear
half moons to battle with the dawn Black
palms rocking oceans Talking

They shed her beads each autumn,
Scraped clean this August, Rusted
long, aching ghoul, Discipling Oshun.

She cups their breasts to Olokun,
Taught tributes flowing, Fee his fond.
Black palms, rocking oceans,
talking drums.

Seven women rattle old, oh, goo,
Breathing coals to baptize this pong.
Aching goods decipher ring, oh, shoo.
She denies the blood red urge to run.

Sister warriors, we're Burnt, burnt,
knives drawn, black palms, rocking ocean,
rocking ocean, rocking ocean,
drum.

She lights their pyre, ha, to mock
the sun, raffia skirts, praise Oya.

Thunder, yawn, aching
goods, deciphering ocean.

Ah, black palms, rocking
oceans, into drum, drum.
Thank you.

I know we're a little
bit over, but we're almost finished.

Um, next we have Erica Jackson, followed
by Jaifa, I'm sorry, Tyepha Walden.
Good afternoon.
Um,

these are two parts from a five part
poem that I wrote called, um, Brown
Tiles and it stems from an assault that

I suffered in 92 by a boyfriend that
I had with fair skin and blue eyes.

And the first part is the third
part of the five part poem.
It's called Stained Glass.

I fell into a friend last
night, mourning the loss of you.

His laughter and fraternally engraved body
led to Swiss mocha bedsheets and pages of
journals and notebooks, papers crinkling
under our decision, scratching the flesh.

My breath awakened the red hiding
in your thirsty rose sitting in my
windowsill as we drifted to the window.

Faced to cold glass, I clawed
for warmth and passion, but
unearthed a nakedness that runs
deeper than the flesh, the truth.
You raped me,
and I coped.
Buried, hid, and rationalized.
Vindicating the blue pureness of you.
Why?

Behind tear stained glass, I stand before
hallucinating stars and blindfolded trees.

The muteness of nature has
acquitted and convicted me.
And, uh, this is the last part.
It's called Satin Blues.

Um, it, it, I can't explain it,
it's, I just can't explain it.

Um, I wrote it from the
standpoint of a tree.

Any other way I couldn't
have gotten it out.
His skin felt good against my branches.

A blue satin ribbon that danced
around my trunk and played hide
and seek through my leaves.
He gave me joy.

For years he played with me,
around me, under me, in me.
Until the day I saw his eyes.
Blue eyes.
Satin blue.
Poisonous satin.

Hypnotic blue shroud cracked revealing
satin tentacles that overpowered my
branches, leaves forming mock barriers.
Disgraced.
My fruit is violated.

Rooted here in his moment,
waning each time the wind sojoins
through my decaying trunk.

A leaf collapses, asking, Does
stolen fruit still taste as sweet?
Thank you.

Tyepha
Walden, followed by Nakia Green.

Hello, my
name is Tyepha Walden.

And today I'm going to read
a poem called My First Love.

It's a personal letter I had
written to God this summer.

It pains me to know all the
troubles I've been through.

I've turned to alcohol, to sex,
and even to death, before I
turned to you, my first love.

Sometimes I feel ashamed having
gone against your wishes,
time after time after time.

All the things you've given me,
all the gifts you've given me,
excuse me, I had taken for granted.

But still, you continue to
care for me, my first love.
Once I had a terrible experience.
I feared you did not love me anymore.

For months and months I pondered
the thought of living without you.
Oh, how terrible was that thought.
For you are the very essence of my life.
You are the reason I can wake up smiling.
My ever so near, ever so dear, first love.

You've always cared for me
when I didn't care for myself.

You've always looked out for me
when I didn't look out for myself.

And you've always loved me
when I didn't love myself.
My first and only love.
I'm sorry for all the pain I caused you.
I have no excuse.

But on this day, this very moment,
I have this promise for you.

That I will never leave,
nor stop loving you.
My thoughts shall be our thoughts.
My words shall be our words.
And my actions shall be our actions.
For you were, and are, and always will be.

My parent, my friend, my guidance,
my strength, and my redeemer.
But above all, my first love.
Nikea
Green, followed by Patricia Johnson.
Hi,

my name is Nikea Green,
and I'm a senior at Henrico High School.

And this poem is called,
I Really Love You.

And it's dedicated to all the young black
girls whose mothers really love them.
I hear your screams, I hear your cries.
Yes, I do.

Baby, just be still, let
him do what he gotta do.
Before he beats me, or you.
I'm sorry, yes I am.
I love you, I really do.
But what is there that I can do?
He don't want me, he wants you.
And there's simply nothing I can do.

I know he's your daddy
and you're a little young.

But it won't happen for long,
he'll find another kind of fun.
Baby, I love you.

I really do, but there's
really nothing that I can do.
But, I really love you.

Love
Ah, don't lie to me.
The me I used to be.
Dream of being the me I'd be.
Dream the dream I thought would never be.
Dream the
dream so far from me.

A sunshine, a halo, a
orange, pink, and blue.
Dreaming dreams of being, to be.
So for me, I used to be.
So the dreams and fears are not for me.
For me, I used to be.
So for me, I be and need to be.
Dreams of being, let me I be.
Dreams of dreams, my father's dreams.
I love it.

Good afternoon, everyone.

This poem is entitled Maximum Security,
and it's dedicated to Evans Hopkins, a
brilliant writer who is doing life in
a Brookville, Virginia penitentiary.
This darkness doesn't scare me.

No darkness can after Quang Tri Province,
that sticky, heavy night, when there
was no moon, when I had no eyes, when

I had no hands, when everything was
pitch, and the smell of death was strong.

No one died that night, but our fear
had us in body bags, on choppers, in
coffins, in the ground, back home.
There was jasmine in the air.
No one smelled it.

I have stories I can tell
myself to mark the hours.

I will know when it is
morning when it is light.

Even if there are no sounds
outside this darkness, I will know.

I will feel the surge of waking
restless bodies through the walls.
I will feel them as they work.

The weights work, the
tears work themselves.

I will know, and I will feel
them struggling through the
night, calling out, calling.

I have learned from sitting with
men in the dark, with the young
hopeful farmers in Bluefields, the

old patient ones in Four Corners,
the nervous marketeers in Manila.
I have learned how to rein myself in.
I have learned how to watch.

Circumspectly, I have learned how
to let what is going to happen come.
This darkness doesn't scare me.
No darkness can after Quang Tri Province.

That cool, crystal night when the moon
sat plump and regal on a throne of clouds.

When sparks crackled along
the surface of my skin.

When everything was desire,
keen edged and elastic.
We all died that night and woke reformed.
There was jasmine in the air.

We lifted our heads to catch
the fragrance, our eyes shut
to better find the scent.

And we let it take us to our
memories, winsome, fragile
memories of love and coupling.

I could see my small, thin, gap
toothed girl letting my unskilled
lips and tongue taste her smooth skin.
Seeing her then.

I reached for her, my
handheld invisible fruit.

Yes, I have stories I can
tell myself to mark the hours.

I will feel the falsetto
songs of the morning.

I will feel men turning
from sleep and reaching.

I will feel the repetition of
prayers, the flood of invectives,
the proclamations of survival.

I will know when it is
morning and I will be fine.

I will feel men touching
their tattooed places.

And I will feel them rub the history
they have pushed into their skin.

I have learned from sitting
with men in the dark.
The frightened.
Resigned.
Betrayed.
And ecstatic.
I have learned how to set myself flying.

I have learned how to
swim and to become water.
I have learned how to billow.
No darkness can scare me.
Not after Quang Tri Province.
Because I have learned to incandesce.

It's kind of like I'm putting two

I want you to say, shut up, alright?
Somebody says, shut up!
But I keep talking.

The teacher whom trained my brain
from the womb And even if he had
his way to the tomb, says Shut up!

But I keep talking The preacher
that sermon surmounted on the
mount Pounded, pillaged, pounced

the gospel That he only quite well

But I keep talking The man that I admired

I met Mother Nature We had a pleasant
talk She was born in Topeka, stayed there
for six weeks Then moved to Chi town Now

she's moving the world Large auditoriums
are too small for her big heart.
Crowds tighten up until she lets it loose.

I want my children to
read her rather than Dr.
Seuss.

She has more children coming
home than Mother Goose.
Some are young and unrefined like me.
Some are seasoned and scholarly like Haki.
Felt like she was already close to me.
Neophytes new to poetry are curious.
I never knew flowers could be so furious.
Yes.

When she's in Chicago,
it's my kind of town.

Don't call her African

Cause she's my kind of brown.

She can run the NAACP and enlist more

She has no political aspirations.
Children, come home to Gwendolyn Brooks.
